awd_titl_txt: ERA-CAPS: Collaborative Research: Thylakoid ion flux-Linking photosynthetic efficiency with osmotic stress response
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant productivity is dependent on many environmental factors, whether plants grow wild or are carefully cultivated in a farmer's field. Efficient photosynthesis is the key to plant productivity, but soil salinity disrupts electrolytes, the so-called ion balance, in the leaf cells where photosynthesis occurs. Soil salinity is a growing problem globally and will affect worldwide food supplies if not effectively controlled. Deciphering how a plant responds to salinity and regulates its cellular ion fluxes is essential to understanding and potentially improving photosynthesis. This  project identifies specific genes that control ion fluxes and responses to salinity in plants using a specialized imaging system and analysis tools to study their role in plant productivity. The international team will use their findings to develop a computational model to inform and improve breeding programs and to develop more highly productive plants that can tolerate soil salinity. The model will be tested in tomato with potential to have broad impact to assure global food security.

Ion flux across the thylakoid membrane represents a promising target for improving plant photosynthesis, yet knowledge of key components is far from complete. This project brings together an international consortium with complementary expertise in chloroplast ion flux, spectroscopy, phenotyping, ionomics, biochemistry, bioenergetics, and computational modelling. By pursing multi-day phenotyping with dynamic growth lighting, the team has isolated new candidate thylakoid ion flux mutants. The researchers will study the compromised genes and their link to known thylakoid ion flux mediators by pursuing the following aims: (i) complete the thylakoid ion transport protein inventory; (ii) determine the role of thylakoid ion flux interactions in photosynthesis and hyperosmotic stress resistance; (iii) identify the process by which thylakoid ion flux impacts the hyperosmotic stress response; (iv) analyze thylakoid ion flux impacts on key agronomical traits in crop plants; and (v) generate a model for simulating increases to photosynthetic efficiency and salt stress resistance as a function of thylakoid ion flux. The Flux4LIVES project has several broader impacts. Photosynthesis is arguably the most important reaction on earth and a foundation for life. With clear evidence that growth conditions in the field have become more adverse recently, a detailed understanding on how abiotic stress impacts this reaction pathway is needed. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that protect photosynthesis and plant productivity will be key to improving these pathways and thus securing necessary levels of global food production. Since the data obtainedwill be open-access via the existing PhotosynQ database, the global scientific community can apply the knowledge to their own biological and ecological questions and thus further the effort to meet food demands across varying climates and conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was part of the trinational ERA-CAPS funding initiative as a collaboration between Dr. Kunz from Washington State University, Dr. Kramer at Michigan State University, Dr. Armbruster at the Max Planck Institute Golm Germany, and Dr. Veenema Estacion Experimental del Zaidin in Granada Spain.

Through funding of this project, the NSF enabled Dr. Kunz to train two postdocs, four graduate students, and several undergraduates at WSU have. The joined project was designed to broaden the understanding of ion transport proteins in the chloroplasts.

The chloroplast is a small green membrane-bound organelle in leaf cells of plants. Here, photosynthesis the foundation of virtually all higher life on earth takes place. During photosynthesis light energy is transformed into chemically-bound energy. As a result, CO2 is captured from the atmosphere and O2 released. Because of the ongoing climate change, it is important for humankind to understand how plants control and adjust photosynthesis in dynamic growth environments. This knowledge will allow scientists, breeders, and farmers to work hand-in-hand in their efforts to produce sufficient food and bioenergy sources for future generations.

For decades, research on photosynthesis has been limited to static light conditions. A few years ago, Dr. Kramer and his team at MSU built a dynamic environmental photosynthesis imager (DEPI). Initial experiments by the consortium members and other labs revealed that ion transport proteins in the chloroplast membranes are especially relevant to sustain photosynthesis when growth light intensities change as they do in the field. In a team effort the DEPI system was employed to screen large mutant collection of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana to identify new genes encoding for chloroplast ion transport proteins and potential regulators.

Within our first aim, we showed that a K+ channel suggested to be in the chloroplasts is much more prevalent in the vacuole a different organelle with no direct role in photosynthesis (Hohner et al., 2019 Plant Physiology). However, the exitance of a K+ channel in chloroplasts remains likely. Kramer and Kunz collaborated with Dr. Helmut Kirchhoff from WSU to expand a computational photosynthesis model originally designed by Dr. Kramer and his PhD student. Here, experimental data collected in an automated growth facility at WSU equipped with robotics-controlled photosynthesis detectors were incorporated. The insights we gained were published in the journal Nature Plants (Li et al., 2021).

In our second aim, we pursued an in-depth analysis of a previously published plant mutant lacking the chloroplast ion transporter NHD1. In DEPI studies we discovered profound changes in photosynthetic performance. However, most effects were not caused by the loss of the ion transporter but by a second-site mutation, a less common event in the lab. This mutation affected a chloroplast enzyme which is required to shuttle electrons from photosynthesis into the temporal redox storage molecule NAD(H). Dr. Kunz's lab published this study supported by Dr. Armbruster and other collaborators (Hohner et al., 2021 Plant Physiology). Kunz and a PhD student followed up with a review article (Kraemer and Kunz 2021 Frontiers of Plant Science). Another collaborative manuscript with Dr. Kramer authored by a WSU Master student is in preparation.

In the third aim of our project, we turned our focus towards osmotic stress triggered Calcium (Ca2+) transients in the chloroplast. We discovered and describe a new family of ion transport proteins which we coined PLASTID ENVELOPE ION CHANNELS (PECs). Our studies show that plant mutants deficient of the two PEC proteins can no longer trigger Ca2+ transients in their chloroplasts. The study led by a PhD student was published earlier this year (Volkner et al., 2021 Plant Physiology). The discovery of these two ion channels provides insights into the interplay of plant stress perception, the chloroplast ion homeostasis, and potentially fine-tuning of photosynthesis.

In the remaining aims of the project, we supported the work by other consortium members. For instance, Dr. Armbruster and here group have designed several transgenic tomato plants which are currently investigated in terms of their stress tolerance. Kunz lab members have started to analyze the elemental (nutrient) composition of these plants.

All plant mutants generated in this NSF-funded research have been donated to the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC) at Ohio State University. Upon simple online request ABRC will send respective plant seeds to scientists in the US and abroad. This guarantees that our NSF-funded research does not stop here but provides a launchpad for others in the global plant science community to generate new knowledge and to aid humankind. Along the same lines, Dr. Kunz and WSU students designed low-cost plant racks which allow to control the growth light dynamics to simulate natural conditions. The detailed instructions were published in an open access journal (Schneider et al., 2019 Plant Methods). We hope this will encourage research on dynamic photosynthesis regulation especially at less well-funded institutions.
